description.narrative: Insatsen syftar till att bygga upp den afghanska kapaciteten att implementera en nationell handlingsplan för att förbättra kvinnors situation, att stödja kvinnors deltagande och inkluderande i fredsprocesser, att bekämpa könsrelaterat våld och att skapa ekonomiska förutsättningar för kvinnor.

The contribution aims to build Afghan capacity to implement a national action plan to improve the situation for women, supporting women's participation and inclusion in peace processes, to combat gender-based violence and to create economic opportunities for women.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The following is the summery of results achived during the full programme period 2009-feb 2015. The overall objective of UN Women's Country Programme was to strenghten women’s empowerment and gender equality in Afghanistan. This was being achieved through promoting women's economic and political participation, prevention of gender based violence as well as coordination and advocacy. UN Women has been supporting the government, especially the Ministry of Women's Affaris, in all central processes when it comes to the development of policies and legislation on women's rights and security. Sidas support was 62 million SEK. The intervention has contributed to a national action plan for women (NAPWA), the EVAW-law to protect women and girls from violence, the 1325 national action plan, a Women's Economic Rights Strategy as well as mobilised the civil society to provide gender input to highlevel agreement between donors and the Afghan government, like the Tokyo Framework Mutual Agreement. The government has been supported to implement and report on commitments in regards to gender, such as CEDAW and EVAW reporting. In addition, the civil society is supported to develop shadow reports on the same. UN Women's programme has supported female Members of Parliaments and Members of the High Peace Council with knowledge in EVAW law, 1325, NAPWA etc. Community leaders and university students received training in resolution 1325. Before presidential elections 2014, UN Women raised awareness among women on their democratic rights. Organisations in 19 provinces that work with gender-based violence (GBV) are supported through a fund and 17 coordinating commissions on GBV are functioning, report and take action on GBV cases. A database for coordinating information on GBV is established in all provinces. Preventive work against GBV is being done through advocacy work mainly within the law reform process, which has stopped reintroduction of stoning as one example. An evaluation of UN Women's work on Elimination of Violence Against Women was evaluated and could indicate a change of attitude in the society, due to increased level of awareness. The programme also contributed to awareness raising of women's economic rights. Ca 190 young women per year were trained in ICT and English through provincial offices of Ministry of Women's Affair, with the aim of making the women more attractive at the job market. Mentoring and networks between female entreprenuers are supported since 2014. In 2014, Sida and Norway took a decision to enter into a new three and a half year agreeement for continued support with UN Women in Afghanistan. For the new programme phase, more emphasis will be on including men/boys into gender equality work, as well as more alignment with the 1325 agenda. Gender Responsive Budgeting is in focus for the new government from 2014, however requires capacity building. UN Women is Kabul based and has a challenge of reaching out to support Ministry of Women's Affair and women in Provincial Peace Coucils in the provinces.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
